plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub known for its glossy leaves and beautiful, rose-like flowers that bloom in winter, often starting in late fall and continuing through early spring. It thrives in temperate climates and is a popular ornamental plant in gardens.
plants.location: Temperate East Asia, cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica was the original source of the name for the tea plant genus Camellia (Camellia sinensis), although the latter is mainly used for brewing tea.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A perennial herbaceous plant that produces cup-shaped white flowers often appearing in late winter around Christmas time, sometimes extending into January. It favors shaded woodland habitats in mountainous Europe.
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas Rose is not a rose but is a member of the buttercup family (Ranunculaceae). Its toxic roots have been used historically for medicinal purposes.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: An evergreen shrub widely cultivated in subtropical and Mediterranean climates, known for its clusters of fragrant, showy flowers blooming during mild winters and spring. In warmer areas, it can bloom sporadically year-round.
plants.bloomingSeason: December to October in mild climates
plants.funFact: Oleander is highly toxic if ingested, yet it has been used medicinally in traditional medicine; all parts contain poisonous cardiac glycosides.

plants.name: Banksia integrifolia
plants.description: A coastal tree native to eastern Australia that produces creamy yellow cylindrical flower spikes. It blooms during the cooler months, providing an important winter nectar source for birds and insects.
plants.funFact: Banksia flowers are composed of hundreds of tiny individual flowers packed densely together, attracting a variety of pollinators including birds and mammals.
